questions.question: What UNESCO World Heritage Site in Africa is known for its rock-hewn churches, believed to have been constructed in the 12th century?
questions.context: The site features 11 medieval monolithic cave churches, and it remains a significant pilgrimage site for Ethiopian Orthodox Christians.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Asia is famous for its large brick stupa that claims to contain relics of the Buddha?
questions.context: This site is where Siddhartha Gautama is said to have attained enlightenment under the Bodhi tree, making it one of the most important pilgrimage sites for Buddhists.

questions.question: What renowned UNESCO World Heritage Site in Europe is an iconic prehistoric monument composed of a ring of standing stones, believed to date back to 3000 BC?
questions.context: Located on the Salisbury Plain, its purpose remains a subject of speculation, ranging from astronomical observations to religious ceremonies.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in South America is celebrated for its well-preserved Inca architecture and terraced slopes, believed to have been built in the 15th century?
questions.context: Nestled in the Andes Mountains, it was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911 and has become a symbol of the Incan Empire.

questions.question: What UNESCO World Heritage Site in the Middle East is known for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system, dating back to the 4th century BC?
questions.context: Also known as the 'Rose City' due to the color of the stone, it was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom and features iconic structures like the Treasury (Al-Khazneh).
